title: What will the end-of-day closing value for the British pound against the US dollar be on 30 December 2016?

The exchange rate is now about 1.18. The economic forecast for UK and EU are about the same for next year (about 2%) and for both countries a lot of uncertainty is expected, and although the M&A market in UK (from outside UK) is quite strong, my estimate is that the GBP will still lose some ground against the EU.

Fears of the GBP reaching parity with the dollar by the end of the year were a little overblown. Since the Brexit vote, the lowest the GBP has been is $1.21. The exchange rate has been between $1.20 and 1.30 since the end of September. While there has been an upward trend the for the past month or so, it is unlikely it will break $1.30 by the end of the month. The is especially true with the renewed confusion around Brexit.

Currently £1 = $1.27 but the pound moved up as the idea of a transitional period after Brexit has emerged from Hammond and the House of Lords in the UK, and noises from the EU Parliament negotiators that they did not rule out such an idea.

No upside surprises expected on dollar strength. 
Relatively low vol FX environment.
Strong pound chance  - momentum - Brexit unexpected news
Reducing the tails for passage of time and relative stability in the fx markets.

There are no more meaningful drivers of the exchange rate before end-2016. I bet that normal market volatility won't push the pound outside the 1.2-1.3 range. As for unanticipated shocks, such are possible, but with the pound near the middle of the 1.2-1.3 range, the risk of getting out is low.

Following the Brexit vote the pound never exceeded 1.4 and current economic data, including hypothesis of U.K. paying for access to EU market do not suggest significant changes from current situation in 1.20-1.30 range. Possible a further drop, if upside than almost certainly in lower 1.30 range. However, nothing is impossible, so I leave a 1% for over 1.50.

The rate backed by fundamentals (historically and potentially) should definitely be over 1.30, unless the BOE begins a new round of unconventional policy measures, which certainly won't happen before year-end.
The pound has been getting stronger and is moving towards 1.30.

1. Estimate based on looking at the support and resistance on the chart.
2. It is likely that Fed will increase US interest rates in December. That may cause US dollar to rise. However, it seems that effect of the rate hike on US dollar has already been factored in the price. 
3. Assuming Fed increases US interest rates, then will Bank of England also follow suite - thus causing British pound to rise? Forecasters believe that UK interest rate increase won't come until the first quarter of 2017.

There are no important economic indicators due to this date, the only major variables are the political ones. UK parliament is paralysed by its own cumbersomeness, giving us no difference in trend; however, I cant discard Trump making a massive PR catastrophe, neither the announcement of a terrible cabinet
Chancellor's statement didn't rock the boat too much. Next thing to watch are the Supreme Court deliberations in December - are they public?

Current rate is 1.24 and range over last 3 months has been 1.21 to 1.33. Forecasts are generally for rate to be at around 1.21 to 1.24 for next 3 months.
Autumn statement seemed to provide small boost to £ with investment in productivity measures.
Adjusting certainty for passage of time.

Trump didn't tank the dollar (as was my previous forecast). The pound briefly went above 1.30 in August, but don't know what would bring it back by December 30. It also hasn't gone under 1.20, although it has gotten close.

The 1% in 1 minute jump that occurred on 21 Nov seems to point to the situation that when ever Theresa May opens her mouth in public the pound will do something ridiculous. However, the near future outlooks for both currencies seem slightly upward, with the pound still lower than fundamentals would suggest due to Brexit anxiety, and US inflation expectations working themselves into the dollar, hence the relationship could remain more or less stable for the next month.
The high interest rate differential to the US, probably disappointing British GDP figures due to trade restrictions and the uncertainty of a post-Brexit environment will harm the Pound further.
BREXIT vs Trump balance more of a feeling than an analysis.

Trump has been elected, although still a lot of uncertainty around what it means. However, inauguration is after the closing date, so less chance of a shock. Since the election, has been trading in the middle of the band. Still a chance of an increase in US interest rates in the near future, although that is probably priced in. If it doesn't happen, or Trump does something to spook the markets, some chance of a weakening of the dollar. But likelihood of remaining in band increasing as we move towards December.
Adjusting to take some account of FX movements on the election of Donald Trump.

With the uncertainty of the election over and Merkels statement that the EU can and will work with the Trump Administration I think the Pound recovers a little but will jump considerable as it submits the Brexit decision to Parliament, thus ending that uncertainty as well.
Flipping less than 1.20 and 1.20 - 1.30 inclusive; on account of election adding uncertainty to value of dollar, and slight improvement to GBP.

The court decision in the UK to make the Parliament vote on Brexit has made the pound rally already. May will try to appeal the decision, which means there is no way that a vote will be held before 2017. The Bank of England might cut rates further, but that is probably mostly been priced in. The big mover will be the USD in the aftermath of the Trump presidency, it might rebound slightly before years end, but doubt it will be enough. For the 1.22 threshold to be crossed something really momentous is going to have to happen in the US (positive) or UK (negative) and I feel given the current trends of these countries economies that's not going to happen.
Trump is in. HRC is out. Uncertainties will push the dollar down and make volatile. Decreasing chances for strengthening the dollar

This forecast assumes that Brexit will go ahead as voted in the referendum in spite of current legal challenges, and that most of the decline in the pound has already been priced in by markets.

Supreme Court ruling regarding Britains exit of the EU in support of parliamentary approval on terms of exit will factor highly as will the result of the US presidential election. A Trump victory will likely cause a drpo in the dollar against most world currencies.

It is unlikely that Brexit decisions will move greatly towards a hard exit before this time - the high court judgement if anything delays the crunch point. The big uncertainty is the US election. If Trump wins, this is against the expectation, and will lead to more uncertainty as people are unsure how a Trump administration is likely to play out. This would be likely to weaken the dollar. The values need to be revisited following the result.  The UK economy is doing reasonably well at present, and the inflation due to the devaluation is yet to feed through. I think barring a shock, more likely to dip below 1.20 than go above 1.30, but most likely to remain in the band.
The pound is recovering fast on short sale covering, I suppose. 1.3 is in sight again.
With US uncertainty over Presidential Election and UK uncertainty over direction of Brexit there are potentially a wide spread of possibilities.

Several recent development reduced downside risks to the pound:
 - the High Court decision on the parliament's vote on Art 50 reduces the political risk of hard Brexit;
 - the macroeconomic data for Q3 were better than expected, reducing the risk of further monetary easing, and
 - the BoE together confirmed that, with a somewhat hawkish statement,  Next to watch: the Chancellor's November mini-budget. And, of course, the Supreme Court ruling on the government's appeal of the High Court decision.

If the Supreme Court agrees in December and Parliament has to agree A50 then the markets are likely to assume that Parliament is more likely to insist on the terms of the Brexit negotiations and  will make it a lot less likely that the government will interpret that the referendum result in a way they damages the UK economy.

Pound has somewhat stabilized around 1.22.  I think there is still more downward pressure having to do with Brexit than upside potential.  Further, the bell curve fits in the neighborhood of 1.20.  Thus, 50%/50%. It would be interesting (and sad) to be making this prediction for a year from now. Well, US 3qt GDP (advanced) estimate came out better than expected - 2.9% vs 2.5%. That increases chances for the Feds to increase rates and put down pressure on the pound. The pound lost some ground in the morning, but than recovered. So, again, most probably it is not about fundamentals, but expectations - soft vs hard Brexit...

Strong growth data out of Britain prompted the worst daily sell-off in government bond for months and pushed yields on the world’s benchmark bonds higher on Thursday, as expectations eased for a Bank of England interest rate cut. "UK growth confounds gloomy predictions
Economy expands 0.5% in the three months after Brexit vote" (FT.com today)

I am not a guru in these matters. Still, my thoughts on the matter. The pound/dollar exchange is driven by sets of multiple factors, but we can distinguish two of them. One set is fundamentals - growth of economy, trade, monetary policy...  Another is political factors, mainly comments and expectations that drive soft vs hard Brexit. Today  a positive GDP growth in the 1st quarter after Brexit was announced - it was weak, but the expectations were for close to 0 or even negative "growth". The slide of GBP/dollar was arrested, but it didn't quite jumped on these news. Of course, partly it is because tomorrow another number will be announced - US GDP growth, which can drive the exchange in the opposite direction. But part of it, I think, is a growing possibility of the "hard Brexit", which is driven by politics. At this moment, it's politics, rather than fundamentals, rule... My personal opinion. Do not pretend to know The Truth. See ya tomorrow!

With CETA negotiations becoming nearly impossible due to minute areas, and the Independent reporting that the pound is now at 1.22 and has lost 1/5 of it's value since the referendum, it's hard to picture the pound on the upswing by the end of the year.

Two major factors are working against the duo GBP/USD - high possibility of hard Brexit and the Fed rate hike in December. Most of that is already priced in. But  certainty for either may well push the GBP below 1.2

Even with fairly strong data still being shown by the Brits and slowing data in the US coupled with good odds of a rate hike in the beginning of Dec we can see that the data is pointing towards pushing the pound under the 1.2 mark...this will soon be the odds on favorite

This might be totally flawed logic and contains some broad estimates ... and importantly I'm not an economist!! ... Today we are at 1.23.  Looking at other GJP questions / Betfair, it looks like odds are 80/20 Clinton/Trump. Assuming that in the eyes of markets Clinton = good for USD and Trump = bad for USD then I estimate election effect to be Clinton will cause USD to be +2%, Trump -8%.    Then we have possibility of US rate rise in Dec - estimate this at 75%. This might strengthen USD by 1%. If doesn't happen, might weaken by 3% (assuming 75% chance is being priced proportionately) Then there is Brexit concern / Autumn budget on 23 Nov. Feels likely this will warn Britons of tough times ahead ... and approaching Article 50 trigger ... so might be another catalyst for notch down in sentiment ... estimate 2% GBP decline with 67%, or 4% appreciation with 33% (if paints more positive picture / inflation picking up leading to potential interest rate rises etc).  Putting all this together (8 different positive scenarios with different weights - Clinton yes/no; US rate rise yes/no; positive budget yes/no) results in following rate estimates: <1.2 - 40%
1.2-1.3 - 48%
1.3-1.4 - 10%
1.4+ - 2%
Leaning now more towards a "Probable" 1.20 - 1.30 from a 50/50 chance.

Given that the Pound had a recent, precipitous drop, a some risk was taken off the table and has re-set the floor. If HRC wins in US, there may be a bump up, but counterintuitively it may actually be more pressure on the Pound going out to end of the year because Federal Reserve will feel more free to tick-up rates by a 1/4 at the December meeting. And as we get to end of year, the looming Brexit Article 50 trigger is looming closer. Nobody wants to catch a falling knife. (Hard to say if traders will feel overly threatened by article 50 at end of 2016 since their timeframe of concern is often much shorter.)

The pound seems to have found a short-term trading range of 1.21-1.23 against the US dollar. Next developments to watch:
 - Oct 27: Macroeconomic data for Q3. BoE expects GDP growth of 0.2 percent q/q.  A higher number will be mildly positive for the pound, reducing the chance of further monetary easing, and vice versa. Given that markets assign only a 5% or so probability of further easing at the next BoE meeting, a negative outcome should move the exchange rate by more than a positive one.
 - Nov 3: the Bank of England meeting. Markets will be watching for both the decision and the forward guidance.

Of course, it's political shocks that move the pound most, and these are unpredictable. But I think that after getting burned by her Tory conference speech, PM May and her ministers will be slightly more cautious with public statements before they have something of substance to say.

Readjusting to current spot rate of 1.23

I heard a great quote today.  A person was asking an economist to educate him on exchange rates.  The economist replied back that there are only two rules that are important, and if you remember these rules, you have mastered exchange rates.  1) If the Pound rises relative to other currencies, it is very bad.  2) If the Pound sinks related to other currencies, it is very bad.  The current pound exchange rate is telling us that markets believe that things are very bad in the UK. OK, on to my prediction change.  We appear to have stabilized around 1.22 pounds per dollar.  Assuming this remains true, and adding in random movement in the exchange rate, that would argue for greater than 1.2 but less than 1.3 being slightly above 50%, and lower than 1.2, being somewhat below 50%, and both buckets being the only option.   But, things are not stable.  Although facts will be sparse between now and the end of the year, there will be a constant drum beat of the impacts Brexit will cause to the UK.  Further, the timing of Brexit will become even more firm over the next 2 months, or we will see a lot of chaos.  The news will be negative, with little upside.  This will decrease the worth of the Pound.  Poor UK.  You deserved better. Good link on the impacts already occurring in the science sector:  http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/18/business/international/brexit-may-hurt-britain-where-t-thrives-science-and-research.html
Late updating for the sudden shift down, but sticking to my framework that 1.20 will be a tough barrier to stay below.

GBP USD has historically been higher and a blind base rate would be around 1.5. This is driven by both US and UK forces. On the UK side, Brexit has clearly changed this rate, and since Brexit the rate has been around 1.30 on average. Recently the value has decreased again, apparently driven by a 'hard brexit' becoming a reality through multiple sources (May speech, EU leaders etc). It is unlikely that information will come to light to bring the rate back to previous levels before negotiations begin. However, the autumn statement may produce some relief with potential announcements of infrastructure investments and trade strategies outside the EU, and given the previous rate post Brexit was 1.3, I don't rule out it being between 1.3-1.4. It could also be the case that as prices in supermarkets are effected, as has started to happen, public opinion may shift, making a 'soft brexit' more likely, which could boost GBP. Again, this means 1.3-1.4 should not be discounted.  However I still see this chance as low as uncertainty is unlikely to decrease. Between now and 30 Dec, EU leaders may position themselves in a tough stance against the UK, meaning the value could drop further. The 'flash crash' also shows that uncertainty is high, increasing the chances of future decreases. The flash crash may also have provided the impetus for those concerned about Brexit to sell, meaning GBP may level out around current levels (1.21).  On the US side, it looks unlikely that Trump will be elected, which would have swung the exchange rate in GBP's favour. However, this is still possible and therefore provides further reason to think 1.3-1.4 is not impossible. It is unclear to what extent the markets have factored the US election into their current forecast as recent price changes appear to have been dominated by Brexit globally, and it is therefore possible that a Clinton election would boost the US dollar and drive the exchange rate against Sterling further (there may also be no change).  Overall I see it as being more likely to decrease than increase, and based on the current rate of 1.21, less than 1.2 is most likely.
Brexit negotiations begin in March 2017. I expect a slow decline in value from now until then.

The pound will keep drifting down towards the 1.10 mark until the UK government signals it is listening to market concerns. The problem is that the UK government is at the moment only listening to public opinion on Brexit. At some point public opinion will (presumably) start to notice the consequences of Brexit and once more than 50% of the public are more bothered by higher prices in the shops and the risk to their jobs than by xenophobia the government will change course. I suggest reading the Daily Mail to spot when it changes its mind.

Updating my univariate time-series forecast early in light of the sharp slump of the past week. This forecast treats the current rate as the end-of-October rate in a model that uses monthly data and then looks two months ahead. Unless there's another sharp move in the next two weeks, I probably won't update again until the end of October.

Keeping up with consensus and market developments.

Adjusted as the pound continues to fall. I am assuming that it will continue to drift lower until the future of the UK re Brexit becomes clear. The success of UK MPs being able to get Parliamentary oversight on the Brexit terms will determine if there is any partial recovery or a faster drop. King's (former governor of the BoE) remarks that a drop is good for the UK economy will encourage speculators to bet on the drop continuing. (note; many economists think King is wrong, over the last couple of decades lower currencies have not produced higher growth. In the case of Brexit UK where there is not a lot of spare capacity, where investment in plant and machinery is said to be falling and where labour shortages are likely if immigration is reduced, it is difficult to see how a lower pound would boost output. The current UK problem is not that the currency is too high, but that there is no confidence in the future.)

Taking some insurance against a fall below 1.2 given recent weakness. For what's it worth, here are some arguments why I think the largest probability is still for the 1.2-1.3 bucket. Would be interested in arguments in favor of the 1.3-1.4 bucket - the consensus still gives that one a 35% probability. As always, if the facts change, I am always willing to change my view :): - Economic perspective: as capital flows into the UK are going to slow, the pound is rightly depreciating to help the current account deficit decline. But if the IMF's "limited scenario" (see Table 1 on p. 32 in http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2016/cr16169.pdf ) is right, the external trade deficit (a large part of the current account deficit) is going to decline quite a bit in 2017 as the economy weakens, with only limited depreciation (5-15 percent on a real effective basis). As we are at the upper bound of this range already, I judge a sustained decline below 1.2 (some 18% decline from the June 22 level of 1.47) not very likely by end-2016 (it may still happen in 2017, though). - financial market perspective: JPM now forecasts the pound at 1.21 by end-2016 (http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-10-10/pound-fails-to-shake-off-wounded-image-after-week-of-flash-crash). It's likely that their traders target this level as well (yes, it's close to 1.2, but still above). Roubini Global Economics predicted 1.22 as well. Moreover, the sharp decline in the past week indicates that many investors were caught longer in the pound that they would like. Once they adjust their positions, and/or shorting the pound becomes crowded, this trade would be vulnerable to sharp rebounds.  - international/policy perspective: markets expect with large probability that the Fed will raise rates once by end-2016 (in Dec.). On the other hand, it's not quite clear what the Bank of England will do in this timeframe. Given the pound's weakness (which amounts to some relaxation of monetary conditions) and the resilience in the real economy indicators, it's likely that they do not relax policy further in this timeframe. I don't think this has been entirely absorbed by the markets.

Base information: Price today = 1.23. Days until deadline = 63. Volatility over last 63 days = 0.021. The talk is moving towards a "hard Brexit", which will mean more uncertainty and a negative outlook for the Pound. Almost as significant is the relatively positive outlook for the US economy, although a rate hike is beginning to look unlikely before the end of the year. Hence, the USD would be expected to perform strongly against all other major currencies, since the outlooks for the Euro area and Japan are significantly worse than the US. A major unknown is the result of the US election, though I'm going to go out on a limb and assume nothing too disruptive to markets (ie Trump presidency) will occur.

My forecast on August 1st was 15% chance of less than 1.20. Starting to look conservative. The pound is now a political currency not based on fundamentals.  At some point there will have to be a reckoning between the UK government's Brexit rhetoric and economic reality. But will this come before the end of the year/before the pound slides below 1.20? Doubtful.

Currency traders are expecting the fall in the pound to continue to. (e.g. to £1.10  to $1, and by the end of 2017 to parity). They are not agreed on the timing. There are several arguments why they expect this.  
e.g. UK Trade minister has said pound is/was too high; Hollande & Merkel are saying EU must not give the UK a sweet Brexit deal; the implied criticism of Mark Carney in Mrs May's Conference speech (denied of course, but the fact it was denied shows that the independence of the BoE is being raised); the contradictory statements at the Conservative Party Conference - free trade and protection, open for business and list of shame for businesses that employ foreign labour, cutting immigration and industries that will be given a free pass to employ foreign labour, the value of foreign labour and the need to train up Brits so the foreign labour can be sent home;  the need for low interest rates for borrowers and the need for higher interest rates for saver; the need to maintain fiscal credibility while increasing government spending and putting off balancing the budget. 
It might sound good to Party members, but it does not sound anything like an economic strategy. Its the typical talk of populists and economies run on populist rhetoric tend to have currency collapses.  
If currency traders see a drop in a currency as a one way bet, then it takes a significant event to change and stop the fall being a self fulfilling prophesy.

Looks like the firming belief in a "hard Brexit" outweigh the recent positive economic news. So even if Q3 data (to be released on Oct 27) prove better than expected, the pound' bounce may be minor. Moreover, at current levels the pound has depreciated by only 14 percent since June 23, much less than the 25 percent drop it experienced in 1992 when the pound was ejected from the ERM. I am starting to lean toward the 1.2-1.3 bucket again.

We need to take into account that the pound dollar rate is not all about the UK end of the equation. What happens to the world and what happens in the USA is also important. The drop in the pound since the UK referendum shows that the market is not looking at what is currently happening to the UK economy but what the market thinks will be happening to the UK economy in the medium and long term. So the UK figures for Q3 will not make much difference. What happens in the wars in the middle east, as the US Presidental election could weaken or strengthen the dollar. As could other significant world events. I am not sure that the market as fully priced in a "hard" Brexit. We are getting very contradictory messages on Brexit (Fox and one group of Brexiteers are saying people voted for Free Trade, Free Markets and no protectionism and no subsidies, while it appears that May is saying that people voted to be protected from Globalisation, which presumably means more protectionism and subsidies.)  As the PM seems to back protection it seems likely that's the way the UK will go, but it is not clear how happy the Free Trade Brexiteers will be.

Key Fermi Factors effecting GBP/USD exchange rate next few months:
I  adjusted odds -  placing lower weight on US Pres election result and more on currency news events including actions by Fed and BoE.
1. Revised chance of UK interest rate decrease by end of year to 25% from 29% (Sunday telegraph 3-sept)
2. Chance (probability 61% see below) of US interest rate increase by end of year stated by US Fed Yellen in August Jackson Hole meeting. Results in buying USD. 
3. CLinton wins election for USPres. Results in buying USD. TRump wins , results in USD selling. 
4. If all the above and Clinton wins Pres election, then results in buying USD and exchange rate could move below 1.20, but more likely 1.20-1.30, as 1.20 is strong psychological logical support level. 
5. If none above apply then exchange rate likely remain above 1.30 
6. If negative US data before end of year , no interest rate increase, And/or Trump becomes US Pres. result is selling of USD, and exchange rate could move above 1.40 
7. A combination of poor US data, Trump win, and good UK data - resulting in buying of GBP, selling of USD, could move exchange rate above 1.50. Although 1.50 is a strong resistance level so more likely to be 1.40-1.50 level. 
8. A combo of 6 and 7 above plus uk raises interest rates, resulting in strong buying GBP and selling USD could move exchange rate above 1.50.

5% over 1.40
15% under 1.20
The 80% in the range, I'll assign as: 45%:35%, favoring the lower rate

As widely expected, the BoE slashed base rates to 0.25%, and noted the sluggishness in the British economy. Benchmark 10-year UK gilt yields fell to 0.63%, and the GBP weakened. The updated forecast is a function of these developments. Two opposing forces are likely to influence the future path of the GBP.  1) Lower rates, and expectations of a weakening economy relative to the US economy, may influence further weakening in the GBP through December'16. Contingent on evolving positive development in the US economy, and signs of weakness in the UK economy, the GBP may continue on a downward trajectory. It seems unlikely, at this stage, that the GBP may experience an incremental 8-10% depreciation from present levels through Dec'16; necessitating a rethink in my probability weights. Part of the reason for a high probability in the original forecast was to account for the likelihood of a 'risk-off' posture towards GBP post Brexit.  2) Return of GBP's 'safe haven', and 'relative positive yielder' status among developed markets may cause the GBP to stem its depreciating trend.
The latest round of QE may have a similar effect on the GBP as  the JPY's experience with Abenomics after 2013. The monetary expansion in Japan helped weaken the JPY versus the USD over the subsequent two years. However, once the JPY's 'safe haven' status was re-established, the JPY appreciated versus the USD.
The 10-year UK gilt still offers a positive yield, compared to near-zero or negative yields in other developed market sovereign debt. Additionally, with the BoE's impending purchase of government debt, and Mark Carney's assertions against dipping into negative interest rate territory, may help put a base under the GBP. In this scenario, the GBP may not only plateau around current levels; but may evolve on an appreciating trend through Dec'16. The updated probabilities reflect these thoughts, as of the current date.

Exchange rates are like share prices themselves forecasts (obviously if you knew what the exchange rate will be in 6 months you would act on the information which would change the rate today.) 
The current rate has factored in all known information so what will prevent the rate staying at today's level must be unknown or unexpected information. This could be something that particularly affects the dollar end or the pound end. The most likely surprises would concern the US elections or Brexit. So my forecast is based on the likelihood that surprises that affect the exchange rates are more likely  than is usual so the range of movement in the exchange rate is likely to be higher than normal.

This may be a little strange way of thinking about it but I prefer to decompose it into eur/usd and eur/gbp (I find it easier to conceptualise and hopefully takes out some of the brexit emotion).
Eur/usd has struggled to trade below 1.075 in any material way despite the best efforts of the ECB, and as the EU still has a current account surplus, and is beginning to show signs of life, I will put the floor for that pair there. On the high end of the range I have 1.14 as negative rates should cap any rally, as should the uncertainty around brexit, and other european issues (although Italian banks getting resolved conclusively, might make me want to reevaluate this upper range). 
On eurgbp, you have large trade ties and no treaty changes until 2 years after the Art 50 trigger, so pair should likely continue to trade within their 10y range of 0.66-0.95. Narrowing that range further I don't see us revisiting the high set during the crisis in 2009, but brexit implications should force the pair towards the upper half of the range, which gives 0.79-0.88. Combining the two ranges you get 1.22-1.44, so will put 4% for both below 1.20 and above 1.44 to cover extremes outside that range. Doing a simple proportional allocation for the other 92% over the 22 pt range you get 33,42,17. One final adjustment would be the limited time frame, which suggests getting to 1.44 might be too extreme, so will move 8% down to the 1.30-1.40 bucket.
Most Brexit info already built into the price. If the Scottish referendum heats up that could change things.

Events that may weaken the pound: the decision in the UK to formally exit the EU and further global economic instability that may lead money to flow into the US. It seems unlikely the Fed will raise interest rates again this year. The possibility of Trump winning the US election should be taken into account, as the dollar would likely weaken, and remain low through the New Year, if Trump wins.   Right now the ER is 1.31. It has strengthened somewhat since reaching its low point. I don't think fall below its post-Brexit nadir (1.28). The high in the last year is 1.57. I also don't think it will get much stronger than that but a Trump victory may push it above 1.50. It was last above 1.50 in December; the Fed has since raised interest rates. The Upshot gives Trump a 24% chance of winning; 538, 45%. Splitting the difference puts Trump's chance of winning at 35%. If Trump wins I think there is a 75 percent chance the ER falls below 1.50. The fed clearly has the ability to stabilize the dollar by raising interest rates, but this will also weaken the economy, which may make them unlikely to do so. Maybe I am too worried about Trump's affect on the ER, but promises to rip up trade agreements and "restructure US debt" seem like good ways to convince investors to sell dollars.

My forecast for continued GBP weakness is based on the relative difference in strengths of the British and US economies over the next 6 months. Continued economic improvement in USA, and re-adjustment pressures in UK following Brexit may weigh negatively on the GBP. A rate hike in the US, and slow economic progress in UK could set the stage for continued GBP weakness. Some historical precedents also provide perspective. Following the onset of the Great Depression in 1929, Britain was the first major nation to relinquish the Gold Standard. This led to a weakening of the Pound, consequently helping the British economy recover the quickest from the economic downturn. Brexit, even though an unplanned decision, may well have set the wheels in motion for a UK economic recovery. A weak currency may aid this process.

Has held steady in the low 1.3 range since Brexit vote. Further political instability could make it drop below 1.3, but I think that's rather unlikely. Small chance that improvements in financial and political stability could pop it back above 1.4, but that's also unlikely. I doubt there will be enough turmoil to send the GBP outside of the 1.3-1.4 range.
The Pound Sterling will remain strong, but not as strong as before Brixit.   All will be well in the UK after a short adjustment period.
Trump presidency likely to provide significant $ volatility.
My initial median prediction gives a 50/50 chance of being above or below 1.3, but it skews because of potential damaging factors, and relatively few chances for positive fluctuations.
Will tend to weaken in the next few months as negotiations and issues begin to appear.

The current impasse, which will likely last a while, seems to have put a floor under the Pound. At the same time, I don't see much propping up the Pound either. The referendum outcome limits options for backpedaling and returning to the status quo. We have instability without chaos, and I think that will keep the Pound range-bound.

As the negative economic effects of Brexit become visible, the Bank of England will keep easing monetary policy. However, most of this effect is already anticipated, so only surprises will count (e.g., deeper/shallower than currently expected economic slowdown). Moreover, the US Federal Reserve will likely stay on hold in 2016 as the effects of Brexit reverberate through the global economy. These factors will likely lead to only moderate deviations from the current exchange rate of 1.31.
Recovery of the pound Q3 2016 due to Theresa May providing some certainty, followed by slight drop in dollar after US general election in November will leave £ up on the compared to today (July 2016)
Britain will still be in the Eu at that point, scotland will still be negotiating and article 50 will still not have been enabled.

We will see the Bank of England raise interest rates enough to attract buyers/investors. Given the  lack of many alternative positive return bonds it should allow for rebound between 1.40 and 1.60 of the pound.
Current rate is 1.32. Most likely outcome is status quo. Rates above 1.40 are common historically. The biggest uncertainties I consider are the the UK brexit impact and the US elections.

The rate is currently about 1.33. From 2009 to mid 2016, the mean appears to be marginally above 1.5. If the trade negotiations (full single market access) conclude favourably for Britain, let's assume the rate will revert to 1.5. However that might be knowable 3 years from now. Factors assumed to cause downward pressure by 30 Dec 16: 
1. Article 50 triggered. Davis stated he would intend to trigger by end of 2016 / start 2017. Hence assume that this factor is somewhat priced into the current rate. 
2. BoE eases monetary policy. Assume likely.  
3. Preliminary UK / EU talks show that a good deal for the UK is unlikely. Estimate 50 / 50. 
Thus, estimate a central tendency rate of 1.3.

New PM installed in better than expected fashion means we're probably at a relative high point. I think more likely than not things will get worse before they get better WRT negotiations are article 50 speculation.

The pound sits at 1.3355 this morning. After the Brexit it dipped below 1.3, but it has mostly hovered between 1.3 and 1.35. This range is a 10 year low for the pound and it reflects a good deal of negativity about the Brexit. Although many (most?) analysts are predicting that the pound will go below 1.3 by year end, it seems unlikely since very little will happen on the implementation of a British exit from the Eurozone between now and then. Important to factor in that weakness in the US markets could push the pound back toward or above 1.4.

It is unlikely that there will be any 'shocks' (i.e. actual withdrawal from the EU) between now and Dec 16 on the UK's side, hence all I can see is that it steadily rises back up from the 1.32 it's at as I write this. The question is whether the US Pres election of Nov 16 will have any impact on the exchange rate.
Plenty of gloom is arguably priced at current levels (1.32). But the problem is that no one really knows.

The shock has happened, there will be limited economic data that is influenced by Brexit before the end of 2015, risk is skewed to the downside as US starts a rate rising cycle and QE looks to be ramped up in UK

Took the current price as the best guess of what it will be, and used historical daily data for last 170 days, making outliers a bit smaller (exceptionally big due to Brexit vote) and adjusting the average price move so it came to zero.
In less than 6 months, I'm not expecting it to move very much.

GBP will lose some of its status as a safe-haven for risk-free securities, hence increased risk of less 1.3
Current market is between 1.3 to 1.4 currently, but with uncertain future trade with EU and possible volatility from political discussions, likely be a slight discount if negotiations fare poorly
Upside potential due to positive negotiations, supportive fiscal/monetary policy (likely) and continued positive econ news.

The evidence is that exchange rates are mostly random walks. (GBP might appreciate slightly due to its higher interest rate, but I didn't account for this.) I assumed a normal distribution with a volatility of 10% per annum on the level of the spot rate. This volatility estimate wasn't really based on much as I had little time to make this forecast; could be wrong.

Confession. I am like a Mini me version of George Soros, or at least I want to be. I do personally plan to hit the pound harder than Mike Tyson hits a punching bag. But I have solid reasons for expecting that to be the case. 1.DB forecasts that the pound will reach $1.15 against the dollar by the end of the year, against the current exchange rate of just shy of $1.30, and it reckons a euro will buy you 90p, up from its current rate of 85p. The forecast follows an equally pessimistic call from Goldman Sachs earlier in the week, which said the pound could hit $1.20 soon. Deutsche Bank’s George Saravelos says his forecasts “look aggressive”, but says: “Our assumption is that the UK is undergoing an unparalleled negative “terms of trade” shock, which requires GBP to reach historical (under)valuation extremes. As the charts below show, there is much more to go before GBP is considered excessively “cheap”.”
http://www.businessinsider.com.au/deutsche-bank-pound-to-fall-by-the-end-of-2016-2016-7?r=UK&IR=T 2. UK needs foreign funding. It has a negative outlook on its credit rating by all 3 Big Credit Rating agencies.  AA 	Negative	
Aa1 	Negative	
AA 	Negative
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-kingdom/rating 3. UK has high levels of debt and exposure to EU banking failure will hit the economy hard.
UK National Debt Surpassed £1 Trillion. Combined with ratings downgrades, the question becomes if the
UK can service its debt. Poor economic growth doesn't give much confidence. http://www.nationaldebtclock.co.uk/
